basis: The user explicitly commits to following the plan (log at 7:30, attempt yogurt cue, log even if late) and expresses readiness to use prompts to stay on track, indicating high likelihood of action.
cognitive_dissonance: Moderate. The user acknowledges drift and memory unreliability but couples this with strong commitment to simple routines and external prompts, suggesting internal conflict between improvisation and adherence.
negative_thought_patterns: Drift tendency; unreliable memory around eating; concern about forgetting; potential overwhelm.
emotional_triggers: Heat and dehydration; fear of losing track; need for reminders and prompts; possible overwhelm.
coaching_notes: Maintain ultra-simple, tangible actions; continue providing prompts and reminders (e.g., 7:30 PM) to support adherence. Validate feelings of overwhelm and encourage timely clinician outreach when needed. Reinforce small successes to sustain motivation.
